newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Spanish tomatoes imports boosted by Medfly co.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Spanish tomatoes imports boosted by Medfly co.

text.p: Improved control of the Mediterranean fruit fly (Medfly) in northern Spain's Almeria Province boosted imports of tomatoes in February through New York's JFK airport, USDA officials said.

Cindy Hettich of the U.S. Department of Agriculture said that in February JFK's imports of tomatoes from Almeria totalled 778 tonnes compared to 196 tonnes a year earlier. Israeli tomatoes imports in February were near stable at 518 tonnes against 527 tonnes in February last year.
Ron Campbell of the USDA permit unit said that since a 1994 rule change there have not been any Medfly cases in Almeria.

Strict regulations cover U.S. imports of Spanish tomatoes. There is a very low rate of Medfly in Almeria. And as it has a low survival rate in the winter months, a restricted shipping period between December 1 and April 30 is now allowed by the USDA from greenhouses registered with the Spanish Ministry of Agriculture.
The USDA sets strict controls regulations whose enforecement means cancellation of exports from any greenhouse where a single Medfly is captured until the source of infestation is determined.
